newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turk shares rebound on secularist pact prospect.
newsitem.headline: Turk shares rebound on secularist pact prospect.

text.p: Istanbul shares rebounded strongly in mid-afternoon trade on Tuesday after a dissident government MP said his planned alternative coalition excluding the ruling Islamists would aim to rule rather than hold fresh elections.
The IMKB National-100 which dived 2.3 percent to a low of 1,363 at the start of the second session, recovered to 1,389 at 1158 GMT, down 0.43 percent from Monday.

"This government will not be for elections it will be a solution government," former trade and industry minister Yalim Erez told reporters after talks with a leftist leader on setting up a new coalition excluding the ruling Islamist Welfare Party.
Brokers said Erez's remarks reduced political uncertainty to some extent.

"Erez's and Yilmaz's words are signs that the talks on forming a new government will produce a result. Political uncertainty lifted a little, so players began to buy on fresh expectations," said Haydar Haydaroglu from Halkbank.

Erez earlier met Mesut Yilmaz, the leader of the main opposition party, who said the two agreed fully on a coalition formula that would shut out the Welfare Party of Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan after 11 troubled months in power.

Erez and another deputy from the junior coalition partner conservative True Path Party resigned in late April in protest at the Islamists' failure to back an army-inspired crackdown on religious activism.
The government has been deeply divided over the reluctance of Welfare to support reforms of the education system which it fears would erode the role of religious schools in Turkey.
